<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Math - Geometry

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> ArcTangent of ''x/y''. Used to determine the angle of a vector ''[x,y]''. Result in [[Number#Degrees|Degrees]] between -180 and 180.
<br><br>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> Informative </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> This command can handle ''y'' being 0, unlike when using [[atan]], and will return 90 </value></part></template>
<br>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> important </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> Even though this command is a binary operator just like [[select]] command, it has [[SQF_syntax#Rules_of_Precedence | higher precedence]] than [[select]] command, therefore the following expression: <br><tt>_pos select 0 [[atan2]] (_pos select 1)</tt><br> will produce an error. The correct usage in this case will be: <br><tt>(_pos select 0) [[atan2]] (_pos select 1)</tt></value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> x '''atan2''' y

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value>  x: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value>  y: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]] 

<br><br>[[Image:atan.jpg|200px]]
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_xy = [5,3];
_degrees = (_xy [[select]] 0) [[atan2]] (_xy [[select]] 1); //59.0362</code>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> Get direction from _obj1 to _obj2:<code>_vd = [[getPosASL]] _obj2 [[vectorDiff]] [[getPosASL]] _obj1;
_dir = (_vd [[select]] 0) [[atan2]] (_vd [[select]] 1); //_dir range from -180 to +180 
[[if]] (_dir < 0) [[then]] {_dir = 360 + _dir}; //_dir range from 0 to 360</code>

</value></part><part><name>x3</name>=<value> Get relative direction from _obj1 to _obj2:<code>_xy = _obj1 [[worldToModel]] [[getPosASL]] _obj2;
_dir = (_xy [[select]] 0) [[atan2]] (_xy [[select]] 1); //_dir range from -180 to +180 
[[if]] (_dir < 0) [[then]] {_dir = 360 + _dir}; //_dir range from 0 to 360</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[atan]], [[tan]], [[sin]], [[cos]], [[asin]], [[acos]], [[rad]], [[pi]], [[vectorCos]], [[getPos]], [[getRelPos]], [[Math Commands]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on 08:00, 18 November 2009</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:KeV|KeV]]<dd class="note">
To get the direction of an object from the player: 
<code>_dir = (([[getPos]] _obj [[select]] 0) - ([[getPos]] [[player]] [[select]] 0)) [[atan2]] (([[getPos]] _obj [[select]] 1) - ([[getPos]] [[player]] [[select]] 1)); 
//_dir will be from -180 to 180.
</code>
If positive values are needed then use:
<code>[[if]] (_dir < 0) [[then]] {_dir = _dir + 360};
</code>
Or just use [[BIS_fnc_dirTo]] directly.
<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
